participant.affiliation: Deputy CEO, Chief Operating Officer & Director

plist.p: Thanks for joining us today in this room or online. Today is Valentine's Day or Ballantine's Day as we call it internally. But well, I guess this is not the only reason why you are with us, even if you're in love with Pernod Ricard. So to present our half-year results, we have today on stage, Pierre Pringuet, CEO and Vice President of the Board of Pernod Ricard; Alexandre Ricard, CEO – Deputy CEO and COO; and Gilles Bogaert, Managing Director, in charge of Finance. They will take one hour also to walk you through the presentation, and then we'll have time for your question. So Pierre, the floor is yours.
Good morning, everyone. Yes we can toast St. Valentine, the results are good. Of course, I will share the presentation with Alexandre and Gilles. So let's go quickly to the introduction.

So good performance and of course, this is despite the less buoyant environment. You probably remember that when we presented our full-year result last August, we did say yes, you have to expect that the environment would be less buoyant.

Having said that, this is the case obviously, for Southern Europe but emerging market continue with seeing very dynamic growth, with a slightly slower pace but really with double-digit growth, I mean, it's good in many countries. And U.S., U.S. is good. I mean, that's really the good news. I mean the – we – it's almost two years now that we have good performance in this very, very important market.

We have the technical impact, mainly it's about France. And the loading of the trade which we did last November, December 2011 in anticipation of the duty hike which took place on January 1 and you can see that it's a significant impact. It represents in term of profits, €64 million. We have also the Chinese New Year. It will be slightly later this year than the year before, which means that we have a more modest impact of €8 million under profit. That would be detailed later on by Alexandre.

Numbers now, so sales €4.9 billion, which is plus 6%; organically, it's plus 3%. And if you exclude the impact of the trade loading in France and Chinese New Year, it is plus 5%. And we think that's the true underlying performance of the group.

And the profit from the recurring operation €1.459 billion, again, plus 6% that's the reported growth; organically is plus 1%. But if you exclude, again, the technical impact of the trade loading in France and Chinese New Year, it's plus 7%.

We do believe that the underlying trend of our business are these plus 5% in term of sales and plus 7% for the profit. And you can see that yes, it has a positive impact on the operating margin and again on the right hand side column at 29% plus 8% (sic) [29.8%] (3:35), that's an improvement of 68 basis point.

There is also this element of comparison, basis of comparison. If you look at the top of this chart, 2011/2012, Q1 and Q2 were extremely high at plus 11% and then Q3 and Q4, respectively, at plus 3% and plus 4%. If you compare now that with our performance this year, you can see that the plus 5% is very much in line or even slightly improving from the last two quarters. And the second quarter reported a plus 1% that, excluding the technical impact, at plus 5% is very much in line with the first quarter. So we can say that we have a steady and consistent growth rate of 5% organic sales, excluding this technical element.

Regarding the portfolio, we obviously were – we had a very good performance overall with our Top 14, but also of our key local brands. And again and in the combination of having international and very strong local brands is for us a very important asset. Indeed we have very good growth with Martell and Jameson. We have a good performance on white spirit but a rapid slowdown of Scotch whisky, but it is also a question of a high base of comparison. Chivas was, for instance, double digit in the first half of last year. So the comparison of two – the basis of comparison is taken into account.

We have continuous favorable price mix, and this is the case for Top 14. Alexandre will give the numbers later on. And a very strong dynamism of our Indian whiskies, and whereas in this country, we're strengthening our leadership position in the premium end of those locally made whiskies, and the premium end is, by far, by far, the most dynamic part of the market.

By market now. Emerging markets are still buoyant, I mean plus 14% overall, with Asia plus 13%, China 18%, India 17%. Definitely these are two main growth drivers that many other countries like Vietnam, for instance, are still developing fast. Strong dynamism in Eastern Europe at plus 12%, and this is mainly driven by Russia, Ukraine, Poland.
And in mature market, well we said contracted solid growth in the U.S., that's what I mentioned earlier, of plus 9%. I mean we can be very pleased with that performance.

France of course, the reported growth looks appalling, minus 28%. But again this is really the counter-effect of the trade loading last year. If you look at what we consider – the underlying trend is more in the low-single-digit decline, so minus 2%, minus 3%. If you for instance at the Nielsen numbers, the market is at minus 3%, Pernod Ricard is at minus 1%. So we're overperforming the market. So at the end of the day, we are we can say that our performance is certainly satisfactory in France in the context of the duty hike.
And challenging environments in Southern Europe, particularly in Spain. Having said that we had a good month of January. So there must be some movement in some of – stocking in this country.

So overall, the pattern which you know well I mean. And definitely the worldwide exposure. I mean Pernod Ricard, where the world – where the 80 countries and all the affiliates give us the opportunity to capture every single growth relay in this market for the wine and spirits. Alexandre?

Thank you very much, Pierre. So again, as Pierre mentioned, our half year net sales grew organically by 3%, or by 5% excluding technical impacts mainly related to the French pre-buying in December 2012 ahead of the duty hike. Second key message, basically very marginal group structure impact. And thirdly, a very favorable Forex impact with the euro-dollar parity at $1.27 over the first semester versus $1.38 the year before.

If we have a quick look, a quick zoom on the quarter, on the October, November, December quarter, net of growth of 1%. But again if we exclude technical impacts, it's 5%. And here the message is very clear. As Pierre mentioned, it's perfectly in line with the trends we experienced in our Q1.

So if we look at the regions, this is the summary table. I'm going to dive in each one of them. But overall what we can say is dynamic growth of 11% in Asia/Rest of the World, strong growth of 6% in the Americas region, a contrasted performance in Europe excluding France of minus 1%. But again that's related to an ongoing bipolarization with Western Europe down 4%, but a very dynamic Eastern Europe up 12%. And finally the decline in France, I'll dive into this later on, but as Pierre mentioned, largely exacerbated by technical and conjunctural impacts.

So to start with our most important region, which is 41% of our net sales from a group point of view. Asia up 11% organically with – from a brand point of view, Martell, very strong growth, very dynamic performance of Martell, up 25%.

And this despite the slight economic slowdown in China. Just to mention as well, a very marginal impact related to the Chinese New Year and this is just because of our commercial strategy aiming at preempting the shelves on the ground in China ahead of Chinese New Year.

Very dynamic performance of our Indian whisky portfolio, up 21%. We have strengthened our leadership in the most profitable and most dynamic segment of deluxe and premium whiskies. We've increased our share up 4% in this most attractive segment.
Our Top 14 Scotch whiskies have had marginal growth in our H1. This is principally related to a challenging South Korean market for Scotch whiskies and second, for conjunctural decline in China.
Our new growth drivers in Asia have developed very well with Absolut, for instance, in Asia up 38%, with our champagne, Perrier-Jouët and Mumm, and finally our wines, which have grown 20% in Asia.

Imperial – South Korea up 12%. Market share gains albeit bolstered by price hikes, so pre-buying in December because we increased our prices on January 1. And finally, 100 Pipers, which is still suffering, down 7% mainly driven by Thailand.

From a market point of view, well very dynamic growth still in China, up 18%. As I mentioned, driven by Martell, up 27%, which continues to gain share. Conjunctural difficulties as mentioned in the Scotch whiskey market. The whole market as well is down. And very strong growth of Absolut and Jacob's Creek are key growth relays.
In Vietnam strong double-digit growth for our key brands such as Chivas, Martell and Ballantine's.

India, overall up 17%, driven both by our local Indian whiskies, Royal Stag, Blenders Pride, Imperial Blue, but as well by other brands such as 100 Pipers. And clearly as well, our Top 14 brands posting strong double-growth as well.

Africa and Middle East up 13%, clearly driven by our Top 14 brands. All of our whiskies in that region are posting strong double-digit growth. Just to remind you that we have recently opened subsidiaries or offices in Namibia, in Kenya, in Angola and Ghana or – in Morocco or even in Nigeria.

Travel retail continues to be dynamic, up 15% driven by our premiumization strategy in high-end brands. South Korea, as I mentioned, there is a decline of the traditional on-trade market, which we are compensating with targeting the modern on-trade with some of our key brands, mainly Absolut.
Thailand, the environment remains challenging but our Top 14 brands are growing strongly.
Japan, up 3%, which is very good growth driven by our Top 14 brands, especially Perrier-Jouët and Mumm, which are both posting strong double-digit growth.
Finally, Australia, strong growth for our Top 14, but again, our high-value strategy for our premium wine brands has resulted in a slight sales decline in our first half.

Moving on to Americas which is 26% of our group sales. Americas posted a solid 6% organic growth driven by our Top 14 up 7% with Jameson, Glenlivet, Absolut and Malibu driving this growth. Our priority wines have continued to grow principally in Canada, where they posted double-digit growth. And it's fair to mention as well, very strong double-digit growth for some of our key local brands, such as Something Special in Venezuela or Passport in Mexico.

Moving on to the U.S. within the Americas region. Clearly U.S. is the key growth engine for Americas, posted a solid 9% organic growth. There's dynamic consumption for Pernod Ricard brands in the U.S. If you look at the Nielsen or NABCA numbers, Nielsen, our volumes were up 1%, 4% in value, NABCA 2% and 6% in value. Clearly driven by the Top 14 with a very strong price mix impact of 3%.

As well as it would be interesting to mention the very good performance of some of our other brands such as Avión, which is doing extremely well, very promising start for Avión, Mumm Cuvée Napa, Seagram's Gin up 3%, or the promising launch of Oddka. I'll just dwell on it a little bit later on.

And if you look at all of our Premium brands, whether it's Absolut with 1% increase in net sales. We started increasing prices in six states. We're launching next month Elyx. With Jameson still speeding up at plus 24%. Malibu up 10% with a confirmed growth, thanks to the innovation strategy behind Malibu. Beefeater up 16% with the revival of the gin category. Perrier-Jouët up 17% with a strong price and mix impact and very good performance of Belle Epoque within the range. And finally Glenlivet where we have increased our price, very strong pricing power. The brand is up 21%.

Brazil, well a favorable underlying trends. If we look at the Nielsen data with Absolut posting 20% growth or Chivas 12% or Ballantine's 25%. Now we are – we have had a slight sales decline in the first half. This is mainly due to a difference between shipments and depletions related to the tax reform over there and the decrease in stocks in the market.

Mexico, well renewed growth, 8% during the last quarter, 5% over the six months. And you can start seeing that the new business model is in place when you look at the very favorable price mix up 7% for our top 14 strategic brands.
Canada, the growth is driven principally by our wines, posting double-digit growth, Jacob's Creek primarily but as well Wiser's, Glenlivet or Jameson.

Travel Retail has been stable. This is due to an unfavorable comparison versus last year, but the trend will clearly improve. We've seen it already improve in Q2 and should improve further in the second half.
And finally, well very strong performances most of the other markets. Just to take an example, in the Andean markets, up 20%.

Europe, one-quarter of our group net sales, up – well actually down minus 1% but a contrasted performance with the ongoing bipolarization. On one side you have a very dynamic Eastern market up 12% and a challenging Western European market down 4%.

From a brand point of view, the key growth driver are our Top 14 strategic brands, with Jameson, Chivas, Absolut, Havana Club and Beefeater driving that growth. The first half has been challenging for Ballantine's, which is down 7%, with a difficult Scotch market in Spain, which the Scotch market in Spain is down 9%.

Overall stability for our wines, which is very encouraging given our premiumization strategy. And finally our key local brands have posted a slight decline with again, contrasted performance with, on one side, strong growth of ArArAt, Olmeca, Seagram's Gin in Spain or Wyborowa in Poland. And on the other side, a challenging first half for Ramazzotti related to commercial issues, Ruavieja in Spain or Becherovka in Czech Republic, which was hit by an overall industry ban for a couple weeks in September.

So from a market point of view, Eastern Europe up 12%, mainly driven by Russia, which was up 22%. Poland has experienced a slight decline, but that's mainly due to local vodka brands. But on the international brands, strong growth, except for Ballantine's, where we have a clear premiumization strategy with a strong price mix impact of 5%. Czech Republic, as I mentioned, related to a ban of two weeks back in September. Strong growth in Ukraine, driven by Jameson, Absolut, Ballantine's, ArArAt, and actually all of our brands. Just to mention as well, Kazakhstan, very promising market, up 29%, good market of 20 million people.
Western Europe, well the decline mainly driven by a challenging Southern Europe and Spain's decline, minus 9%. And as Pierre mentioned earlier, actually we had a pretty good month of January.

Now France, 8% of group sales, clearly a decline of 28% exacerbated number one, by very strong technical effects, and number two, by conjunctural effects. Technical effects represent close to €100 million from a net sales point of view. And excluding that technical impact, we're down 11%. Now that's mainly as well due to conjunctural effects, which we have here on the chart. Residual inventory in market in Q1 2012/2013, lower inventories mainly due to a prioritization by our key customers on beer ahead of the duty hike on beer, and finally, promotional offers that were not repeated this year.

So the actual real underlying trend on a net sales point of view specifically for Pernod Ricard is actually minus 3%. And if you look at the market trends from a Nielsen point of view, as Pierre mentioned, we have gained share. The market is down 3% in volume terms, and this is the Nielsen off-trade data. And Pernod Ricard was down just 1%.

The most challenging category, the one that had suffered most, is the Pastis category. But in that category, Ricard has gained share, down 3% versus minus 5% for the category. Some of our brands have suffered, such as Malibu and Chivas. But very strong performance of some of our other strategic brands, such as Ballantine's up 4%, Jameson up 5%, Absolut double-digit growth, and to mention Havana Club, the best performance, all brands in the industry in France. Some tactical brands as well have performed very well. So overall France, market share gains.

Very briefly and from a brand's point of view, so our premium brands now represent three-quarters of our sales, so their weight is increasing. Strong growth excluding technical impacts, up 7% for our top 14, 2% for our wines, 8% for our local 18 key brands, and the rest minus 3%. Therefore, posting a 5% increase in net sales.
Just to mention we have a zoom on our top 14 brands. Despite minus 5% and plus 4% from the sales point of view, if we exclude technical impacts, volumes were almost stable and sales grew 7%.

So if you look at the table here, you'll see that all of our brands have posted a positive price mix, which is very good, up 8% excluding organic – excluding technical impacts. And this is because we have – we're focusing three quarters of our investments behind them, and actually they represent 90% of the growth of our A&P over the semester.
So I've mentioned the price mix is favorable, very favorable. Excellent performance of Martell up 23% and Jameson up 13%.

Our white spirits have performed very strongly. Absolut is recovering in the U.S. and is experiencing very strong growth in emerging markets. Havana Club has improved in terms of trends, driven by Europe, Germany in particular, and as I mentioned, France as well. And Beefeater is growing very well in the U.S. I mentioned, but as well in Europe in difficult and challenging markets such as the U.S. – such as Spain, sorry.

Near stability for our Scotch whiskies but again they grew very strongly last year during the same period up 12%. There is a very favorable price mix for all of our Scotch whiskies. And again, as I mentioned, conjunctural slower growth in China, structural slower growth in South Korea, difficulties in Spain, and a few unfavorable technical impacts.
The decline of Ricard, I mentioned it, principally to technical and conjunctural effects.

And finally, contrasted performance of our champagne brands. Very strong performance of Perrier-Jouët and Belle Epoque driven actually by all regions, and a decline of Mumm, which is primarily due to a strong exposure to European markets, including and specifically France.

Our wine strategy, very encouraging, stable volumes, 2% net sales growth and double-digit growth from a profitability point of view with a strong diversification from a geographical point of view, which helps profitability especially driven by Asia.

Our 18 key local brands have grown excluding technical impacts by 8% in volumes and 8% in sales. This is principally driven by our Indian whiskies up 21%, but as well by Passport, which were targeting the emerging middle class with, up 14%.
Strong performance of brands such as ArArAt, Olmeca especially in Russia, or Something Special especially in Latin America.
Imperial, again bolstered by a price hike on January 1. And finally a few, well, brands that are challenged, such as Pastis 51 and Clan Campbell, but as well with the unfavorable technical impact.

Very briefly, you have it in your slides, premiumization, innovation, expansion into new territories or consumption modes. Well we've just gathered a few examples of marketing initiatives or innovations, such as partnerships in the art and fashion community with Pernod and Maison Kitsuné or Ricard with Mathieu Mercier or Perrier-Jouët with Claire Coles or the partnership between Absolut and Art Basel.

From a consumer base point of view, expanding into new consumption modes with Kahlúa Midnight launched in the U.S.; or Brancott Estate Flight, lower in alcohol wine, just 9%; with Chivas Brothers Blend, much smoother, exclusive to the travel retail market; or Malibu Island Spiced, stronger taste but lower in calories.

Limited editions with the very, very successful Absolut Unique. Just to remind you, that is 4 million bottles, each and every single one of them unique. Or Jameson, great urban escapes. We have here as well Ballantine's.

From a flavor point of view as well, we've been very dynamic. Oddka, I mentioned it earlier, has just been launched. Innovative flavors such as Fresh Cut Glass – uh yeah, Grass, sorry, such as Apple Pie or even Electricity. Kahlúa, a new holiday flavors. Other examples as well from a consumer experience point of view, with Ricard Twist'R to have people try and taste Ricard under new forms. And new Rituals with a cocktail approach or a pack-in offering approach with convenience packs for Ritual. Or convenient format such as the Kahlúa cans.

As well from a digital point of view, we've been very active creating buzz with the Havana Club Gap Year. If you want to take a full year off, well there's a nice competition going on on the Web. With Ballantine's, where actually you can transform pictures into music. And with the iPad app that we have developed for The Glenlivet.

And finally, regarding our very premium brand Martell, we've developed a new ad campaign stressing the authenticity of Martell, but as well we have the same regarding the Mojito Embassy for Havana Club or This is my London communication campaign, very successful in Spain for Beefeater. Or again The Legacy Tasting program for The Glenlivet. Thank you.

Thank you, Alexandre. Let's go back to the figures. Talking with that overview of the summary income statements. As we can see, as Pierre and Alexandre said, we had a good performance. Excluding the technical effects, organic growth for sales was up 5%, it was even more than that for the operating profits up 7%. And we have some operating margin expansion by 68 basis points.

Looking at the different effects on the operating profits, from an organic growth standpoint, it was up 1%; 7% if we exclude the technical effects. And as Alexandre said, we had a very favorable ForEx impact in the first half because of a stronger U.S. dollar. ForEx will be obviously different in the second half. Currently the price of euro-dollar is near from $1.34. And last year it was $1.30. So as a consequence, for the full fiscal year 2012/2013, we estimate that the price impact on profits from recurring operations should be slightly positive.

Let's have a look at the gross margin. As you can see, there was a significant increase in the ratio, up 146 basis points excluding technical effects. Forex was favorable for 50 basis points, but we also have numerous positive business elements like the portfolio mix, which was positive with the Top 14 sales growth higher than the group growth. We had a positive quality mix in particular among the Top 14 brands, representing a 4% positive impact. We have managed to increase prices on average on Top 14 up 4%. And at the same time, we've been able to control the evolution of our input cost, which excluding mix effects were up only 3%.

In terms of A&P, we have increased the A&P by 4%. They were clearly allocated to our priority brands and priority markets. Top 14 was up 5%. We had double-digit growth in both the U.S. and the emerging markets. On the other hand, we had some optimization in the less buoyant markets. We had near stability of A&P in mature markets. At the same time, we were preserving investments in strategic priorities, even in tough market like Spain, where we decided to keep some investments to sustain the launch of the Ritual brand by Havana Club.

The A&P-to-net-sales ratio was almost stable despite unfavorable technical effects. There were some phasing of Absolut investments, because last year investment were lower in the first half as compared to the second half. And in Russia we have pragmatically decided to focus the media spend in the first half. As you can see the A&P increase in first half was clearly above net sales increase, because of the media restrictions taking place on the 1 of January 2013.

In terms of structure costs there was a continued increase in resources allocated to rapidly expanding markets. As you can see we have increased our structure costs in emerging markets by 28% and at the same time, we have almost stability in mature markets. We have the continued expansion of the distribution network, in particular in our most buoyant emerging markets, China, India and Russia, where we still have some geographical expansion to do. And we have also opened new subsidiaries in Africa and approximately 100 people were recruited in that region.
At the same time we have reduction on the structure costs in the less buoyant markets. In Western Europe, they were down 2%. In France, they were down 5%.

And at the end of the current fiscal year, we will finalize the resource expansion cycle originating from the Agility project, which was a – it was a company project that was launched in 2010. And whose priorities were reinforcing our competencies in innovation, in digital, in HR. We have also created a Pernod Ricard University.

So as a consequence the profit from recurring operations is up 7% organically, excluding the technical effects. The operating margin was up 68 basis points, excluding again those technical effects, because there was a significant increase in gross margin, driven as we saw by premiumization, price increases, and input cost control. We also had a control A&P expenditure, and we benefited from a favorable ForEx, which contributed at 28 basis points to operating margin expansion.

Let's have a look at the overview by region from a profit standpoint. As you can see, Asia/Rest of the World continued strong growth, up 19%, same pace as last year. Americas up 6% with some acceleration driven by the U.S.

Europe excluding France there was some slowdown due to Southern Europe, but yet as we saw excellent trend still ongoing in Eastern Europe. And in France, the decline was largely exacerbated by technical and conjunctural effects. You can see that this year it's down 51% and last year at the same period of time it was up 47%, so it clearly shows the importance of those technical factors.

You have here the breakdown of sales and profit by region. I think it shows the importance – the growing importance of Asia/Rest of the World, which now represents almost half of the profit, some 46% of the profit in the first half. And it also shows the more and more limited dependence from the group on the Euro area. In first half it was limited to 20% of the group net sales.

Splits between emerging markets and mature markets, I think that shows again the increased weight of emerging markets, almost half of the group profits. And interestingly enough, you can see that this expansion has a positive impact on the margins, so the profit's growing at a faster pace than the net sales.

So covering the different regions from profit standpoints. In Asia very strong growth in operating profits, up 19% organically, well above the 11% organic sales growth, thanks to an excellent increase in gross margins, which continues to benefit from an improved price and mix, positive ForEx impact also. And A&P was up organically 6%. We also benefited from economies of scale for this A&P in major markets and brands. And as a consequence, we had a substantial improvement in operating margin rate from 31% to 33.6%.

The Americas, there was a strong increase in the gross margin rates, 300 basis points. Almost half of it being organic, thanks to a positive price and mix. We have increased our A&P expenditure in that first half up 13%, so clearly above net sales. That's logical. This is a region where we have a lot of growth ambitions, so we put resources behind that objective. And there was also a technical affecting impact between the first half and second half of last year.
And we continue to increase the resources allocated to our route-to-market enhancements, structure costs were up 8% in particular in Latin America.
Europe, there was a gross margin increase, 1% despite the 1% decline of net sales, thanks to Eastern Europe, which compensate for a challenging environment in Southern Europe.

There was a substantial 7% increase in A&P expenditure in the first half. So the ratio was up because of two conjunctural factors. The first one I mentioned, so media spend in Russia, which was focused on the first half before the advertising restriction came into effect on the 1 of January 2013, and also, as I said, the spend on Ritual in Spain to support the development of this new strategic product.

We had a strict allocation of structure costs with a reduction in Western Europe, minus 2%. And at the same time, a significant increase in Eastern Europe, in particular in Russia of 16%, to strengthen our leadership position and support the geographic expansion strategy to smaller cities.

France, so Alexandre mentioned the technical and conjunctural effects from a sales standpoint. Let's have a look at both effects from a profit standpoint. The technical effect of the pre-buying last year before the duty increase had a negative impact of €64 million. This figure was communicated to you one year ago.

And on the top of that, we had some conjunctural effects, which had total an impact of minus €24 million, because there were already new inventory reduction in the first quarter, the fact that we had low inventories at the end of 2012 in some distributors because of the duty increase on beers, which have led the distributors to put priority to beer loading as opposed to spirit inventories. There were some promotion activities not repeated by major retailers in first half, and obviously we had this decrease in consumption following the excise duty hike that we estimate in net sales, as Alexandre said, at around minus 3%.

So the sum of those two impacts is minus €88 million. And we believe that those effects are now behind us. And for the full year 2012/2013, we see major decline of the profit from recurring operation in France to be limited to approximately €25 million. So as you can see, it's very similar to the impact of the conjuncturing effects in the first half. So in other words, it mean that in the second half, excluding the technical effects, we estimate that the profits will be more or less flat in France.

Let's have a look at the elements below the operating profit, starting with the financial income and expenses. As you can see, we had an average cost of debt of 5.4% in first half, so slightly below what we had previously estimated. It's obviously an increase as compared to last year, because of all the debt refinancing we did last year. As a reminder it enabled us to increase the share of bond debt at a higher level than 80% to extend the maturity of the debt. The average maturity is close to five – to seven years. And to secure attractive long-term rates.

For the full fiscal year 2012/2013, the average cost of debt should be close to the one of the first half, should even slightly decline in the second half. And I think that very bold to say that starting second half, financial expenses will start to decrease, starting now in January. And it will go even further that last – next year, because we'll have a reduction of the average cost of debt to 5% because of some, I would say, costly past financing and hedgings coming to maturity in April and May this year. So we are clearly at the turning point. Starting now you will see financial expenses decreasing as compared to the previous periods.

We have here another view of the cash flow statement. So free cash flow was of – generation of cash of €416 million. As for the P&L, it was largely impacted by technical and conjunctural effects with effects – assumable with effects to be minus €130 million. We have obviously, the French impact which had some impact on the profit but also on the cash. We estimate that the cash impact of that was approximately minus €60 million. You had some first half, second half of phasing differences of certain payments, in particular excise and taxes. And you have an unfavorable base of comparison in working capital. As a reminder last year and also the year before, by the way, we had done some optimization initiatives notably in Asia/Rest of the World, so we had a decrease last year of the working capital, particularly at the end of the June despite the fact that sales were up, so we have an unfavorable basis of comparison.
As we said earlier this year, we decided to increase our strategic investments, both in CapEx and strategic inventories, so it will clearly go on in the second half.

In terms of financial charge and cash tax it was a negative impact of minus €90 million, compensated by improvement on non-recurring items. Coming back to the financial charges, the increase is due to the same reasons for the – that the one I presented for the P&L. And so starting second half and next year, you will start seeing some decline. And the cash tax was up. It includes the impact of the measures in France. So in second half, cash generation will accelerate and hence, contributing to further deleveraging of the group.

We have the evolution of the net debt, it was down €215 million to a bit more than €9.1 billion, particularly due to a favorable ForEx impact. The ratio net debt to EBITDA on this first half was stable, obviously because of the numerous significant and favorable technical and conjunctural effects in first half, which will obviously be down as of end of June.

You have here an overview of the debt structure. I won't comment each figure but just highlighting the key points. We have bank and bond maturities in calendar year 2013 and 2014, which will be covered by forecasted cash flows and existing credit facilities.

And speaking about those credit facilities, we currently draw €0.6 billion from our syndicated loan, whereas we have availability of €2.5 billion. So we have a very solid financial structure. We have time to return our bond maturities, and we have flexibility thanks to that facility.

From a currency and rate standpoint, no change. We keep more than half of the debt in dollar. As you know, this is what we call the natural hedging of the debt. We try to split debt between euro and dollar to mirror our split of EBITDA and cash flow by currency. And we keep a large proportion of the debt at fixed rates.

A word on income tax. There was an increase of the rates, up from 24.7% to 26.8%. As I said in our Q1 communication, it reflects clearly the impact of the tax reforms in France, which cost us on the first half €16 million. So negative impact on the net profit.

For the full year, we now estimate that the income tax rates from recurring operations will be close to the one of the first half, again in particular because of the impact of those tax reforms in France, the 3% tax on dividend and the limitation of deductibility – tax deductibility of interest on debts in particular.
Quick overview on the non-recurring items. All in all the net impact was limited, minus €10 million. And you had in this first half a depreciation of our wine brand, Brancott Estate, by €64 million.
